title: Invalid conflict between trait impls
body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

```rust
trait Trait1<A, B> {}

trait Trait2<A, B> {}

struct MyLocalStruct;

impl<B, T> Trait1<MyLocalStruct, B> for T
where
    T: Trait2<MyLocalStruct, B>
{}

impl<B, T> Trait1<MyLocalStruct, B> for Vec<T>
where
    T: Trait1<MyLocalStruct, B>
{}
```

I expected to see this happen: 

Here these implementations do not conflict as I understand it, and not for any particularly subtle reason. Rust prohibits implementations of foreign traits for foreign types according to the nomenclature of [RFC 2541](https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/2451-re-rebalancing-coherence.md). Now both `Trait1<MyLocalStruct,B>` and `Trait2<MyLocalStruct,B>` are local traits in this crate and in no other according to the rules outlined there (specifically, for a foreign trait to be considered local, it must have generic parameters, and the first generic parameter must be local - since `MyLocalStruct` is local to this crate, there can be no other crates in which these traits are local with these parameters).

Instead, this happened: 

```
error[E0119]: conflicting implementations of trait `Trait1<MyLocalStruct, _>` for type `std::vec::Vec<_>`
--> src/main.rs:12:1
|
7  | / impl<B, T> Trait1<MyLocalStruct, B> for T
8  | | where
9  | |     T: Trait2<MyLocalStruct, B>
10 | | {}
| |__- first implementation here
11 |
12 | / impl<B, T> Trait1<MyLocalStruct, B> for Vec<T>
13 | | where
14 | |     T: Trait1<MyLocalStruct, B>
15 | | {}
| |__^ conflicting implementation for `std::vec::Vec<_>`
|
= note: downstream crates may implement trait `Trait2<MyLocalStruct, _>` for type `std::vec::Vec<_>`
```
Note that the "note" at the very least is incorrect according to my understanding: No downstream crate can implement `Trait2<MyLocalStruct, _>` for `std::vec::Vec<_>`, because that is a foreign trait on a foreign type everywhere except the standard library and this crate.

Note also that removing the `B` parameter makes rustc accept this code, even though according to my understanding of the RFC 2541 rules these two cases should be indistinguishable. 

### Meta
<!--
If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->

`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
rustc 1.60.0 (7737e0b5c 2022-04-04)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: 7737e0b5c4103216d6fd8cf941b7ab9bdbaace7c
commit-date: 2022-04-04
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.60.0
LLVM version: 14.0.0
```
The behaviour of nightly is identical, with nightly:
```
rustc 1.62.0-nightly (4c60a0ea5 2022-05-04)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: 4c60a0ea5b2385d7400df9db1ad04e96f2a4c154
commit-date: 2022-05-04
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.62.0-nightly
LLVM version: 14.0.1
```
